<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Cartoon Dialect Discrimnation.jpeg|thumb|<ref>{{Cite web |date=2021-02-22 |title=Accents, Dialects, and Discrimination {{!}} The Walrus |url=https://thewalrus.ca/accents-dialects-and-discrimination/ |access-date=2022-04-07 |language=en-US}}</ref>]] -->{{Discrimination sidebar}}
'''Dialect discrimination''' refers to the unequal treatment of those whose [[dialect]] contains linguistic features identifying them with a certain geographical or [[social group]]. It is connected to [[linguistic discrimination]] and [[linguistic racism]].<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-02-04 |title=Preventing Linguistic Racism and Discrimination – CETL |url=https://cetl.udmercy.edu/preventing-linguistic-racism-and-discrimination/ |access-date=2023-12-16 |language=en-US}}</ref>
One may experience dialect discrimination in a number of settings, but this type of discrimination may be most prominent in the [[workplace]]. While there is not enough data to know how often it occurs, it is possible that a number of people may experience dialect discrimination during the [[Job application|job application process]], as employers strive for their staff to utilize a more “[[standardized]]” or “neutral” form of speaking.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |last=Connell |first=Shaun |date=2023-05-03 |title=Dialect Discrimination |url=https://writingtips.org/dialect-discrimination/ |access-date=2023-12-16 |website=Writing Tips |language=en-US}}</ref>
Dialect discrimination may also be present in [[education]] and [[politics]]. Children in school whose dialect does not closely resemble the standard form of speaking may not receive the same [[education]]. Likewise, those who speak in a manner that is not associated with the common dialect of an area or country may be [[slandered]] or even unable to vote in politics. It is disputed whether this form of [[discrimination]] is prohibited by the [[Equal Employment Opportunity Commission|EEOC]].
== Connections to other factors == Discrimination can be defined as the unfair treatment of a person or a group based on something for which they identify.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Discrimination: What it is, and how to cope |url=https://www.apa.org/topics/racism-bias-discrimination/types-stress |access-date=2022-04-07 |website=www.apa.org}}</ref> Discrimination is often seen as categorical. Some categorical examples of this include, but are not limited to; [[Race (human categorization)|race]], [[gender]], age or [[sexual orientation]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Discrimination: What it is, and how to cope |url=https://www.apa.org/topics/racism-bias-discrimination/types-stress |access-date=2022-04-07 |website=www.apa.org}}</ref>
Dialect discrimination is linked to perceptions of dialects in relation to race, class, national origin, and other categories. For instance, in the United States, Southern accents are associated with lower class individuals, and there is a resulting reduction in pay offered to those with Southern accents compared to accents perceived as more "neutral."<ref>{{Cite book |last=Baugh |first=John |url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/product/identifier/9781316597750/type/book |title=Linguistics in Pursuit of Justice |date=2018-01-31 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=978-1-316-59775-0 |edition=1 |doi=10.1017/9781316597750.008}}</ref><ref name=":0" />
There is also [[language]] discrimination, when someone is treated/looked at differently than others because of their native language or how they speak the common language of the area (such as English in much of the United States).<ref name=":1">{{Cite web |title=Language Discrimination |url=https://legalaidatwork.org/factsheet/language-discrimination/ |access-date=2023-12-16 |website=Legal Aid at Work |language=en-US}}</ref> This is typically related to dialect and accent discrimination, too. Dialect or accent discrimination, are considered as part of the category of national origin. Therefore, they are covered under the Title VII of the [[Civil Rights Act of 1964]], which prohibits an employer from discriminating against any individual with respect to his or her compensation, terms/condition, or privileges of employment because of that individual’s national origin.<ref name=":1" />
== Examples of dialect discrimination == === Workplace === A good example of dialect discrimination would be workplace dialect discrimination. A lot of times, individuals will not be hired for a job because of the way they speak or sound. And another thing that is difficult and at the Forefront of media, today is the fact that if one's primary language is not [[English language|English]] and one is trying to get hired by an English-speaking company, many companies will not hire this individual because of this. Although this is seen as illegal in many states, it is still a very wide reason why some people do not get jobs. The employer may not tell the employee that that is the reason he or she is not being hired, but usually, it is the underlying cause.<ref>{{Cite web |first= |title=Language Discrimination - Workplace Fairness |url=https://www.workplacefairness.org/language-discrimination |access-date=2022-04-07 |website=workplacefairness |publisher=Midwest New Media |language=en}}</ref><ref name=":1" />
=== Education === Dialect discrimination can be found is in schools. Something that a lot of families struggle with is they will put their child in a school that is primarily English-speaking, and the child will get discriminated against and not get the same tools that other students are getting as far as learning goes because of the way they speak or sound. In the US, [[Hispanic]] languages get looked down on in primary education schools. Because of this, a lot of Hispanic immersion schools have been created, however language and dialect discrimination is the root cause.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Álvarez |first=Brenda |title=Linguistic Discrimination Still Lingers in Many Classrooms {{!}} NEA |url=https://www.nea.org/advocating-for-change/new-from-nea/linguistic-discrimination-still-lingers-many-classrooms |access-date=2022-04-07 |website=www.nea.org |language=en}}</ref>
=== Political === There is dialect discrimination in politics. A lot of times, candidates running for a government position are discriminated against because of the way they sound: for example, people may label a political figure as undereducated based on their dialect and/or accent.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Bonotti |first=Matteo |last2=Willoughby |first2=Louisa |date=October 2023 |title=Linguistic prejudice and electoral discrimination: What can political theory learn from sociolinguistics? |url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/meta.12649 |journal=Metaphilosophy |language=en |volume=54 |issue=5 |pages=641–660 |doi=10.1111/meta.12649 |issn=0026-1068|doi-access=free }}</ref>
